questions.description: Objects in JavaScript are "non-primitive" values. What does that mean?
questions.explanation: The term 'compound' value does not apply to JavaScript. Objects are not immutable by default, and can be modified.

choices.value: It's a compound value by default, composed of other primitives.
It's an immutable value by default, which cannot be modified.
It's a mutable value by default, which can be modified.

questions.description: How can you delete a property from an object?
questions.explanation: The 'erase', 'omit', and 'remove' operators do not exist in JavaScript

questions.description: Select all valid Objects from the list of expressions below.

choices.value: function add(a, b) { return a + b; }

questions.description: In JavaScript, a non-primitive value is one which can be mutated or modified. When a non-primitive value is assigned to a variable, it is said to be a "reference" to the value. What does a "reference" mean?
questions.explanation: The first choice is the best answer;

choices.value: The reference points to the value's location in memory; the variable doesn't contain the value.
The reference is a copy of the original; the variable holds a copy of the value.
The reference is an abstract inlined cached representation of the original non-primitive.
